casebody.data:
Coleman, plaintiff in error, v. The People. A witness for the people stated in his cross-examination that he had taken an interest in the prosecution. On the re-direct examination he was asked the occasion of taking such interest. Held, a proper question. A witness for the prisoner introduced to show that the property was purchased innocently, was asked, in reference to certain property, “ Did you not put railroad brass under skidding * * * and cover it up, after being pur- ■ chased by you, and say that it was railroad iron, and would not do to be ' seen?” Held, proper to impeach testimony of witness as to the innocent nature of the purchases at plaintiff’s store. J. O. Cochrane, for plaintiff in error. G. Raines, district attorney, for the people. Taloott, J.

Evidence—competency of—unanswered question — charge of court.

The prisoner was indicted for receiving stolen property. On the cross-examination of one of the witnesses for the prosecution, it appeared that such witness had found property of his own in the prisoner’s possession. On redirect examination he was asked to describe the property he had referred to. Held, a proper question in order to show that the property mentioned was not that described in the indictment.

The question was answered in the negative. It is well settled that an objectionable question' admitted, but unanswered, forms no ground for an exception.

Where a principle of law is correctly stated in a charge, the counsel has nc right to require the court to charge an isolated proposition on language chosen by himself, or to charge it as an isolated proposition, if it is embraced in the "charge given.

Writ of error to Monroe county sessions.
